metadata.description: English to Luvale dictionary as spoken in North-Western Province, Zambia

examples: How are you? - Munayoyo?
how are you?.usage: Used to inquire about someone's wellbeing

examples: Goodbye - Kalunga mina
Goodbye, see you later - Kalunga mina, nangumona cheka
goodbye.culturalContext: Formal farewell, literally means 'God be with you'

examples: Where are you? - Muli kulihi?
where are you?.usage: Used to ask about someone's current location

examples: Where did you go? - Mwayilehi?
where did you go?.usage: Used to ask about someone's previous destination

examples: Where do you live? - Uli nakutwama ika?
where do you live?.usage: Used to ask about someone's residence or home location

examples: Where are you going? - Uli nakuya ika?
where are you going?.usage: Used to ask about someone's intended destination

examples: Where were you? - Wapwangahi?
where were you?.usage: Used to inquire about someone's previous whereabouts

examples: I am hungry - Ngwakwivwa zala
I am hungry.usage: Used to state that you're feeling hungry

examples: Thank you - Ngwasakwililako mwane
I want - Ngwakutonda
I want.usage: Used to state a desire for something

examples: I have eaten - Ngunali
I have eaten.usage: Used to inform someone you've already eaten

examples: Have you bathed today? - Lelo wasane?
Have you bathed today?.usage: Used to ask if someone has bathed yet

examples: When are you working? - Omu uli nakuzata?
When are you working?.usage: Used to ask about someone's work schedule

examples: What is the time? - Lwola muka?
What is the time?.usage: Used to ask about the current time

examples: Congratulations - Mwazachila mwane
Congratulations.usage: Used to congratulate someone on an achievement

examples: I am sorry - Sesamwane
You are welcome - Ukalu wauchi
You are welcome.usage: Used to respond to someone thanking you

examples: Me too! - Na yami!
Me too!.usage: Used to express that you feel the same way

examples: God bless you - Kalunga akisule ove
God bless you.usage: Used to wish divine blessing on someone

examples: She is happy - Ali nakuwahilila
She is happy.usage: Used to describe someone's happy state

examples: Please help me - Ngunakutonda kukafwo
Please help me.usage: Used to politely ask for help

examples: I have heard - Ngunevwu
I have heard.usage: Used to indicate you've heard or received information

examples: I agree - Nayami nawa mwomwo
I agree.usage: Used to express agreement with someone

examples: Excellent - Camwenemwane
What thing? - Cuma muka?
What thing? - Cuma cika?
What thing?.usage: Used to ask for specification about something

examples: We know that - Tunatacikiza ngwetu
They found them - Vavawanyine
They found them.usage: Used to state that some people found other people

examples: Do you think he is stupid? - Unaxinganyeka, tahi? Ngwove, nahulama
Do you think he is stupid?.usage: Used to ask someone's opinion about another person's intelligence

examples: I don't know - Kangwatacikijileko
I don't know.usage: Used to express that you don't have certain information

examples: I will come tomorrow - Nangukeza hamene
I will come tomorrow.usage: Used to inform someone of your plan to visit the next day

examples: Come here! - Twaya kuno!
Come here!.usage: Used to instruct someone to come to your location

examples: Feel at home - Tambokenu ku zuwo yami
Feel at home.usage: Used to make guests feel comfortable

examples: Be blessed - Kalunga akisule
Be blessed.usage: Used to wish divine blessing on someone

examples: I am coming soon - Nguli nakwiza hono lili
I am coming soon.usage: Used to inform someone that you'll arrive shortly

examples: Excuse me - Sesamwane
Excuse me.usage: Used to politely get someone's attention or to apologize

examples: What are you doing today? - Lelo uli nakulinga ika?
What are you doing today?.usage: Used to ask about someone's daily plans

examples: What are you doing on the weekend? - Lelo uli nakulinga ha weekend?
What are you doing on the weekend?.usage: Used to ask about someone's weekend plans

examples: It is okay - Chamwaza mwane
It is okay.usage: Used to express that something is acceptable

examples: I am going home - Ngunakuya ku zuwo
I am going home.usage: Used to inform someone that you're leaving for home

examples: I don't want - Kangwate
I don't want.usage: Used to express that you don't desire something

examples: Sweetheart - Waha muchima
Sweetheart.usage: Used as an affectionate term for a loved one

examples: Let me try - Eseka
Let me try.usage: Used to express desire to attempt something

examples: Welcome home - Tambokenu ku zuwo
Welcome home.usage: Used to welcome someone back to their home

examples: I reached home safely - Ngwalyhetanga ku zuwo
I reached home safely.usage: Used to inform someone of your safe arrival home

examples: God is good - Kalunga na kanawa
God is good.usage: Used to express faith and gratitude

examples: My name is John - Lijina lyami John
What is your name? - Lijina lyove lika?
I need water - Ngwatonda meya
The water is clean - Meya ali utoma
water.culturalContext: Essential resource in daily Luvale life
water.usage: Refers to the liquid used for drinking and other purposes

examples: How much? - Jingahi?
how much?.culturalContext: Common question for price or quantity
how much?.usage: Used when asking about cost or amount

examples: How are you feeling? - Munayoyo?
how are you feeling?.usage: Used to ask about someone's state of being

examples: What is your name? - Lijina lyami
What are you doing? - Muli nakulinga ika?
what are you doing?.usage: Used to ask about current activities

what are you cooking/eating?.translation: Muli nakuteleka ika? Muli nakulya ika?
what are you cooking/eating?.pronunciation: mu-li na-ku-te-le-ka i-ka? mu-li na-ku-lya i-ka?
examples: What are you cooking? - Muli nakuteleka ika?
What are you eating? - Muli nakulya ika?
what are you cooking/eating?.usage: Used to inquire about meals being prepared or consumed

examples: Are you okay, dear? - Ngachili, waha muchima?
are you okay, dear?.usage: Used to express concern for someone's wellbeing

examples: When are you coming? - Omu uli nakwiza?
when are you coming?.usage: Used to ask about arrival time

examples: How was your night? - Mwasawala ngachili?
How was your day? - Likumbi ngachili?
How are you doing? - Muli nakulinga ngachili?
how are you doing?.usage: Used to ask about someone's state or activities

examples: How is your family? - Thanga yove ngachili?
How was your day? - Likumbi ngachili?
how was your day?.usage: Used to inquire about events of the day

examples: What is wrong? - Ika unalingi?
What do you mean? - Unatalikisa mulihi?
Have you gone to church? - Wayanga ku church ika?
What is this? - Ika eyi?
what is this?.usage: Used when pointing to something unknown

examples: What's going on? - Ika?
what's going on?.usage: Used to ask about current circumstances

examples: Have you heard? - Munevu?
Can I go home? - Ngunahase nakuya ku zuwo?
Please give me. - Nguhaneco mwane
How is everything? - Muli nakulinga ngachili?
What's your phone number? - Phone number yove ika?
Where were you? - Wapwangahi?
where were you?.usage: Used to ask about previous whereabouts

examples: The food is good - Kulya chawaha
I am cooking food - Nguli nakuteka kulya
Yes, I understand - Eyo, ngunevushiwa
Yes, please - Eyo, ngwatondo
yes.usage: Used to express agreement or affirmation

examples: No, thank you - Nduma, ngwatondo
No, I don't want that - Nduma, kangwatonda chizeko
no.usage: Used to express disagreement or denial

examples: Good morning - Chimene chamwaza
Good morning, how did you sleep? - Chimene chamwaza, walala ngahi?
My family is large - Chisaka chami chachinene
Family is important - Chisaka chachilemu
family.usage: Refers to a group of related individuals

examples: My mother is cooking - Mama yami ali nakuteka
I love my mother - Ngwazanga mama yami
My father is at home - Tata wami ali kwimbo
I respect my father - Ngunenga tata wami
father.culturalContext: Highly respected figure in Luvale family structure

examples: The child is playing - Mwana ali nakuhema
I have one child - Ngukwechi mwana umwe
child.culturalContext: Children are considered blessings in Luvale culture
child.usage: Refers to a young person regardless of gender

examples: Our village is small - Mbo yetu yamundende
I am going to the village - Nguli nakuya kumbo
village.culturalContext: Traditional settlement unit in rural Zambia
village.usage: Refers to a small rural community

examples: The chief is speaking - Mwangana ali nakuhanjika
We respect our chief - Twapwa mwangana yetu
chief.culturalContext: Traditional authority figure in Luvale communities

examples: My friend is coming - Sepa lyami ali nakwiza
He is a good friend - Ikiye sepa lyamwaza
friend.culturalContext: Social bonds are important in community life
friend.usage: Refers to a close non-family relation

examples: I am going to the market - Nguli nakuya kuchitanda
The market is busy - Chitanda chizala
market.culturalContext: Center of commerce and social interaction
market.usage: Refers to a place for buying and selling goods

examples: We are planting maize - Tuli nakukuna chimbuwa
The maize is growing well - Chimbuwa chili nakukola chamwaza
I am eating nshima - Nguli nakutafuna shima
Nshima is our staple food - Shima kulya chetu chamuchima
nshima.culturalContext: Main traditional food made from maize meal
nshima.usage: Refers to a thick porridge made from maize

examples: The makishi dancers are coming - Makishi vali nakwiza
The makishi ceremony is important - Likumbi lyamakishi lyachilemu
makishi.culturalContext: Traditional masquerade dancers in Luvale ceremonies

examples: I want one banana - Ngwatonda lizu chimwe
Only one person came - Muntu chimwe kaha ejile
Two children - Vana vivali
I have two cows - Nguli nangombe vivali
two.usage: Used for counting pairs of items

examples: Three days - Makumbi atatu
I need three chickens - Ngwatonda tusumbi tutatu
It is raining - Vula yili nakunoka
We need rain for our crops - Twatonda vula yavitunge vyetu
rain.usage: Refers to water falling from clouds

examples: The sun is hot today - Likumbi lili nakuhinza lelo
The sun is rising - Likumbi lili nakutumbuka
sun.culturalContext: Central to daily rhythms and time
sun.usage: Refers to the star at the center of our solar system

examples: I am eating - Nguli nakulya
Let's eat together - Tulyenu hamwe
to eat.usage: Describes the action of consuming food

examples: I am walking to the village - Nguli nakuyenda kumbo
He walks quickly - Eyi nakuyenda washi
to walk.culturalContext: Common mode of transportation in rural areas
to walk.usage: Describes action of moving on foot

examples: I speak Luvale - Nguli nakuhanjika Luvale
She is speaking with the chief - Eyi nakuhanjika na mwangana
to speak.culturalContext: Oral tradition is important in Luvale culture

examples: My house is small - Zuvo yami yamundende
We are building a new house - Tuli nakutunga zuvo yayihya
house.culturalContext: Traditional homes often made with local materials

examples: The tree is tall - Mutondo wausuku
We are sitting under the tree - Tuli nakutwama mwishi yamutondo
tree.culturalContext: Source of shade, medicine, and building materials

examples: I need medicine - Ngwatonda mitela
Traditional medicine - Mitela yamuchihunda
medicine.culturalContext: Both modern and traditional medicine are practiced
medicine.usage: Refers to substances used for healing

examples: I am happy today - Nguli nakuivwa kuwaha lelo
Today is a good day - Lelo likumbi lyamwaza
I will come tomorrow - Nanguya hamene
See you tomorrow - Nangumona hamene
tomorrow.usage: Refers to the day after today

examples: I saw you yesterday - Nakumona zau
It rained yesterday - Vula yanokele zau
yesterday.usage: Refers to the day before today

examples: I caught a fish - Ngwakwata ishi
Fish live in water - Tushi twikala mameya
fish.culturalContext: Important food source in communities near water

examples: The river is wide - Kalwiji kachikama
We fish in the river - Tuli nakukovela mukalwiji
river.culturalContext: Source of water, fish, and transportation
river.usage: Refers to a natural flowing water body

examples: They are dancing - Vali nakuchina
Traditional dance - Kuchina chamuchihunda
A beautiful song - Mwaso wamwaza
Traditional songs - Myaso yamuchihunda
song.culturalContext: Integral to cultural ceremonies and daily life

examples: He is a farmer - Ikiye kafunga
Farmers work hard - Vafunga vazata chikuma
The farmer is planting - Kafunga ali nakukuna
Farmers work hard - Vafunga vazata nangolo
farmer.usage: Refers to a person who cultivates land

examples: God is good - Kalunga wamwaza
God bless you - Kalunga akukisule
God.culturalContext: Important in spiritual beliefs and expressions

examples: I am going to church - Nguli nakuya kuliuka
The church is far - Liuka lili kwakusuku
church.culturalContext: Christianity has become integrated with traditional beliefs
church.usage: Refers to a place of worship

examples: My brother is tall - Ndumbwami wachalume wausuku
I work with my brother - Ngulinga na ndumbwami wachalume
brother.culturalContext: Important relationship in extended family structure

examples: My sister is smart - Ndumbwami wachapwevo wakuzangama
I visited my sister - Ngwatalilile ndumbwami wachapwevo
sister.culturalContext: Important female relationship in family structure

examples: My grandfather tells stories - Kaka wami alumwine mishikakimi
I visited my grandfather - Ngwatalilileko kaka wami
grandfather.culturalContext: Respected elder who often passes down cultural knowledge
grandfather.usage: Refers to the father of one's parent

examples: My grandmother makes good food - Nana wami enga kulya chamwaza
I learn from my grandmother - Ngulinangula kuli nana wami
grandmother.culturalContext: Source of wisdom and traditional knowledge
grandmother.usage: Refers to the mother of one's parent

examples: My uncle came to visit - Manjina wami ejile nakutalilikako
I respect my uncle - Ngunenga manjina wami
uncle.culturalContext: May have specific responsibilities to nieces and nephews
uncle.usage: Refers to parent's brother or male relative

examples: My aunt gave me a gift - Tata wami wachapwevo anguhane wana
I am going to my aunt's house - Nguya kuzuvo ya tata wami wachapwevo
aunt.culturalContext: Female relative who may have cultural role in raising children
aunt.usage: Refers to parent's sister or female relative

examples: The cow gives milk - Ngombe yahana mavele
We have many cows - Tuli nangombe jivulu
cow.usage: Refers to bovine cattle, particularly female

examples: I am cooking chicken - Nguli nakuteka kasumbi
The chickens are in the yard - Tusumbi tuli muwande
chicken.culturalContext: Common poultry raised for meat and eggs

examples: The goat is eating grass - Pembe ali nakulya jisoji
I want to buy a goat - Ngwatondo kulanjisa pembe
The elephant is large - Ndimba yayinene
Elephants live in the forest - Tundimba twikala muzuvo
elephant.culturalContext: Respected wild animal in African folklore
elephant.usage: Refers to the large pachyderm with a trunk

examples: The lion is hunting - Ndumba ali nakuzuka
The lion roars - Ndumba ali nakuvuma
lion.culturalContext: Symbol of strength and power in Luvale culture
lion.usage: Refers to the large wild cat, king of the jungle

examples: My shirt is blue - Shati yami yauzulu
I bought a new shirt - Ngwalanjile shati yayihya
shirt.usage: Refers to an upper body garment

examples: Traditional cloth - Chitera chamuchihunda
The cloth is colorful - Chitera chajimbalisa
cloth.culturalContext: Used for traditional attire and ceremonies

examples: I am happy - Ngunahwahilila
She looks happy - Amweka kuwahilila
I am sad - Nguli nakuyanda
Don't be sad - Kanda kuyanda
He is angry - Ali nakuhanduka
Don't make me angry - Kanda kunguvisa handuka
Love is important - Zangi yachilemu
I love you - Ngwakuzanga
love.usage: Refers to a strong feeling of affection

examples: I like to dance - Ngwazanga kuchina
We are dancing - Tuli nakuchina
to dance.culturalContext: Important in cultural ceremonies and celebrations

examples: She is cooking nshima - Ali nakuteka shima
I am learning to cook - Nguli nakuhakwila kuteka

examples: She teaches children - Eyi nalongesa vana
I want to teach Luvale - Ngwatonda kulongesa Luvale
I teach Luvale - Nguli nakulongesa Luvale

to teach.usage: Describes the action of imparting knowledge

examples: The wedding is tomorrow - Vimbayila vili hamene

examples: Boy's initiation ceremony - Mukanda wavamalunga
Initiation is important - Mukanda wachilemu

The girls are singing - Tupwevo tuli nakwimba

examples: The boy is running - Kalunga ali nakuhinana
The boys are working - Valunga vali nakuzata

examples: The village elder is speaking - Chilema wambo ali nakuhanjika
Respect the elders - Vumbikanga vilema
elder.culturalContext: Elders hold authority and are repositories of wisdom
elder.usage: Refers to an older, respected person

examples: The teacher is kind - Mulongeshi wakeha muchima
Our teacher knows a lot - Mulongeshi yetu atachikiza vyavivulu
teacher.usage: Refers to a person who educates

examples: The school is far - Shikola yili kwakusuku
Children go to school - Vana veyi kushikola

examples: I need money - Ngwatonda mali
Money is important - Mali achilemu
money.culturalContext: Medium of exchange in market economy

examples: The road is long - Jila yausuku
We are walking on the road - Tuli nakuyenda hajila

examples: The doctor is helping me - Ndotolo ali nakungukafwa

examples: In the morning - Nachimene
Morning is cool - Chimene chatonya

examples: Good night - Usuku wamwaza

We work on the farm - Tuzata halifunga

The garden needs water - Wunda watonda meya

examples: The fire is hot - Kakahya kahinza

We are building a house - Tuli nakutunga zuvo
They built a school - Vatungile shikola

Help me please - Ngukafweko wapwile tamo

Learning is important - Kulinangula chachilemu

examples: I am working - Nguli nakuzata
We work together - Tuzatanga hamwe

examples: She sings well - Eyi nemba kanawa
We are singing - Tuli nakwimba

examples: I farm maize - Nguli nakulima chimbuwa

examples: Good afternoon, sir - Musanya wamwaza, mwata
Good afternoon to you all - Musanya wamwaza kuli enu vosena

We grow sweet potatoes - Tukalanga jimbwita

Beans and nshima - Makunde nashima

examples: Morning prayer - Kulomba chachimene

Fishing in the river - Kukovela mukalwiji

examples: Men went hunting - Malunga vayile nakuyeha

hunting.usage: Describes the action of pursuing animals

examples: The elder has wisdom - Chilema akwechi mangana
Seek wisdom - Tondanga mangana

examples: I want bread - Ngwatondo mbolo
Fresh bread - Mbolo yayihya
How are you young man? - Muli ngahi kanyike walunga?
Good morning, how are you young man? - Mwane, muli ngahi kanyike walunga?

how are you young man.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young man or boy

examples: How are you young girl? - Muli ngahi kanyike wapwevo?
Good morning, how are you young girl? - Mwane, muli ngahi kanyike wapwevo?
how are you young girl.culturalContext: Respectful greeting to a young female, acknowledging their youth status
how are you young girl.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young girl or female child

where can I find mango trees.translation: kulihi ngunahase kuwana mitondo ya mbuma
where can I find mango trees.pronunciation: ku-li-hi ngu-na-ha-se ku-wa-na mi-to-ndo ya ma-ngo
examples: Where can I find mango trees? - Kulihi ngunahase kuwana mitondo ya mango?
I want to know where I can find mango trees - Ngwatondo kutachikiza kulihi ngunahase kuwana mitondo ya mango
where can I find mango trees.culturalContext: Mangoes are popular fruits in North-Western Province of Zambia, though not native to the region. They were introduced during colonial times and are now grown in many villages.
where can I find mango trees.usage: Useful phrase when looking for specific fruit trees or resources in a new area

examples: I saw an animal - Ngwamona tunyama
There are many animals in the forest - Kuli tunyama tuvulu mu zuvo
The dog is barking - Kawa ali nakulila
I have two dogs - Ngwakwata tuwa tuvali
dog.culturalContext: Common domestic animal in Luvale communities

examples: The cat caught a mouse - Kambasuku kwate mbulu
The cat is sleeping - Kambasuku ali nakusavala
cat.culturalContext: Domestic animal often kept to control rodents

examples: The sheep has wool - Mukoko ukwechi mavwototo
The shepherd watches the sheep - Kafunga alinakutala mikoko
sheep.culturalContext: Livestock animal raised for wool and meat
sheep.usage: Refers to the domestic ovine animal

examples: The elephant is large - Ndimba yayinene
Elephants live in the forest - Tundimba twikala muzuvo
elephant.culturalContext: Respected wild animal in African folklore
elephant.usage: Refers to the large pachyderm with a trunk

examples: The lion is hunting - Ndumba ali nakuzuka
The lion roars - Ndumba ali nakuvuma
lion.culturalContext: Symbol of strength and power in Luvale culture
lion.usage: Refers to the large wild cat, king of the jungle

examples: I'm afraid of snakes - Nguli nawoma manoka
The snake is dangerous - Linoka lyalyalumbu
snake.culturalContext: Often featured in folklore and traditional stories

examples: The bird is flying - Kajila ali nakuwuluka
Birds sing in the morning - Tujila twembanga nachimene
bird.culturalContext: Often admired for their songs and freedom

examples: The monkey climbs trees - Kavenga alinakukanduka mutondo
Monkeys eat bananas - Tuvenga twalya makonde

examples: The crocodile lives in the river - Ngandu ikala mulwiji
Beware of crocodiles - Likombelenu tungandu
crocodile.culturalContext: Feared predator in rivers and lakes

examples: The hippo is in the water - Nguvu ali mameya
Hippos are dangerous - Tunguvu twatumbulu
hippo.culturalContext: Common in African rivers and lakes

examples: The ants are carrying food - Tungunji tuli nakuhaka kulya
There are many ants here - Kuli tungunji tuvulu kuno
ant.culturalContext: Symbolizes hard work in many African cultures
ant.usage: Refers to the small insect that lives in colonies

examples: The bee makes honey - Lungoji alinakutengesa wuchi
Bees can sting - Tungoji tunahase kuluma
bee.usage: Refers to the flying insect that produces honey

examples: The butterfly is beautiful - Kapela wamwaza
Butterflies have colorful wings - Tupela tukwechi mavava amilemba
butterfly.culturalContext: Often associated with beauty and transformation
butterfly.usage: Refers to the insect with colorful wings

examples: The mosquito bit me - Mungu angulumika
Mosquitoes carry diseases - Tungu tunatwala mavyaji
mosquito.culturalContext: Associated with malaria and other diseases
mosquito.usage: Refers to the small biting insect

examples: The buffalo is dangerous - Mbovo yayilumbu
We saw a herd of buffalo - Twamona mikoka yambovo
buffalo.culturalContext: Wild animal respected for its strength and unpredictability
buffalo.usage: Refers to the large wild bovine

examples: The zebra has stripes - Mbizi ukwechi misinga
Zebras run fast - Tumbizi tuchilyanga chikuma
zebra.culturalContext: Wild equine with distinctive striped pattern
zebra.usage: Refers to the striped horse-like animal

examples: The giraffe has a long neck - Twiga ukwechi singo yayisuku
Giraffes eat leaves from tall trees - Tutwiga tulya mafwo kufuma kutondolo yayisuku
giraffe.culturalContext: Distinctive tall animal found in African savannas

examples: The leopard is hunting - Chisungwe ali nakuzuka
Leopards are spotted - Visungwe vikwechi matobo
leopard.usage: Refers to the spotted wild cat

examples: The hyena laughs - Chimbwi ali nakuseha
Hyenas hunt at night - Vimbwi vizukanga ufuku
hyena.culturalContext: Often associated with trickery in folklore
hyena.usage: Refers to the scavenging wild canid

examples: The frog jumps - Chula ali nakutukuluka
Frogs live near water - Tula twikala hafwihi nameya
The tortoise moves slowly - Fulwe endanga chochocho
The tortoise has a hard shell - Fulwe ukwechi chikapa chachikuminyina
tortoise.culturalContext: Often featured in folklore as wise but slow

examples: The rabbit is fast - Kalulu wachinyemuka
Rabbits have long ears - Tululu tukwechi matwitwi asukumuka
rabbit.culturalContext: Featured in many folktales as clever and quick
rabbit.usage: Refers to the small mammal with long ears

examples: The spider makes a web - Luvunga alinakutunga vwanda
Spiders catch flies - Tuvunga tukwata tung'onze
spider.culturalContext: Often featured in folklore as clever and industrious

examples: The scorpion stings - Kalalavwa kukoka
Beware of scorpions - Likombelenu tukalalavwa
scorpion.usage: Refers to the venomous arachnid with a stinger

examples: The grasshopper jumps - Litete linatutumuka
Children catch grasshoppers - Vanyike vakwata matete
grasshopper.culturalContext: Sometimes eaten as a protein source

examples: Termites eat wood - Tumvumbi tulya mumbandu
Termites build mounds - Tumvumbi tutunga malundu
termite.culturalContext: Important in ecosystem; sometimes harvested as food

examples: The worm is in the soil - Muka uli mulukungu
Birds eat worms - Tujila tulya tuka
worm.usage: Refers to the elongated soft-bodied invertebrate

examples: The lizard sits on the rock - Mbulu alikwimanyina hachimambo
Lizards catch insects - Tumbulu tukwata tung'onze
lizard.culturalContext: Common reptile in rural and urban settings
lizard.usage: Refers to the small reptile with four legs

examples: The bat flies at night - Liluva liwuluka ufuku
Bats hang upside down - Maluva mahetekela
bat.culturalContext: Associated with night and darkness in folklore
bat.usage: Refers to the nocturnal flying mammal

examples: The mouse eats grain - Mbulu alya jimbuto
The cat chases mice - Kambasuku atumbila tumbulu
Dark clouds are coming - Mavwi amupi ali nakwiza
The sky is full of clouds - Melu azala namavwi
cloud.culturalContext: Important weather indicator for farmers and travelers
cloud.usage: Refers to visible mass of water droplets in the sky

examples: A storm is coming - Kafuku kali nakwiza
The storm destroyed houses - Kafuku kayongwele mazuvo
storm.culturalContext: Often seen as significant spiritual or natural event
storm.usage: Refers to severe weather with strong winds and rain

examples: Lightning struck the tree - Numbwambwa yimbachile mutondo
I am afraid of lightning - Nguli nawoma numbwambwa
lightning.culturalContext: Often associated with spiritual forces in traditional beliefs
lightning.usage: Refers to the flash of light during a thunderstorm

examples: Thunder is loud - Kulunduwa chakuhyakana
Thunder follows lightning - Kulunduwa chinalondezanga numbwambwa
thunder.culturalContext: Often interpreted in traditional beliefs as voices of ancestors or spirits
thunder.usage: Refers to the loud sound that follows lightning

examples: There is a rainbow in the sky - Kuli kongolo mwilu
The rainbow has many colors - Kongolo yakwechi jilimba jajivulu
rainbow.culturalContext: Often has cultural significance in folklore and myths
rainbow.usage: Refers to the arc of colors in the sky after rain

examples: The drought destroyed our crops - Changa yayongwele vitunge vyetu
We need rain to end the drought - Twatonda vula yakumana changa
drought.usage: Refers to prolonged period without rain

examples: The flood destroyed houses - Livaji lyayongwele mazuvo
The river caused a flood - Kalwiji wazachishile livaji
flood.culturalContext: Natural disaster that affects riverine communities
flood.usage: Refers to overflow of water onto normally dry land

examples: Today is hot - Lelo kunahinza
The sun is hot - Likumbi linalimbuha
hot.culturalContext: Affects daily activities and agricultural planning

examples: It is cold today - Lelo kunatonoka
The water is cold - Meya anatonoka
It's windy today - Lelo kuli peho
The wind is strong - Peho yinanangula
windy.culturalContext: Can affect farming, fishing, and other outdoor activities
windy.usage: Describes weather with strong air movement

examples: The rainy season has started - Misongo yinatundu
We plant during the rainy season - Tukunanga hamwakela misongo
rainy season.culturalContext: Critical period for agriculture and water collection
rainy season.usage: Refers to the annual period of consistent rainfall

examples: It doesn't rain in the dry season - Kavula yanoka hamwakela chamwafu
The dry season is hot - Chamwafu chinahinza
dry season.culturalContext: Time for certain harvests and building activities
dry season.usage: Refers to the annual period with little or no rainfall

examples: The morning fog is thick - Fuka yachimene yinazivala
I can't see through the fog - Kanguhasa kumona mufuka
fog.culturalContext: Often associated with early morning or areas near water bodies
fog.usage: Refers to thick cloud at ground level limiting visibility

examples: I like the red cloth - Ngwazanga chitera chachichila
The flower is red - Chiluwa chichila
red.culturalContext: Color often associated with importance and ceremonies
red.usage: Describes the color of blood or fire

examples: The cow is black - Ngombe yachimupi
I want a black shirt - Ngwatonda shati yachimupi
black.culturalContext: Color used in various traditional contexts
black.usage: Describes the darkest color, absence of light

examples: The clouds are white - Mavwi achitoma
She wears a white dress - Eyi wavwala mukuto wachitoma
white.culturalContext: Often associated with purity in cultural contexts
white.usage: Describes the color of milk or snow

examples: The sky is blue - Melu auzulu
I bought a blue shirt - Ngwalanjile shati yauzulu
blue.culturalContext: Associated with the sky and some traditional fabrics
blue.usage: Describes the color of the clear sky

examples: The grass is green - Jisoji jachitema
I like green vegetables - Ngwazanga jimbowa jachitema
green.usage: Describes the color of growing plants

examples: The sun is yellow - Likumbi lyachiyelo
Ripe bananas are yellow - Makonde akuhya achiyelo
yellow.culturalContext: Often associated with sunshine and some fruits
yellow.usage: Describes the color of the sun or ripe bananas

examples: The soil is brown - Lukungu lwasafule
He has brown shoes - Ikiye akwechi jimbundu jasafule
brown.culturalContext: Color of earth and many natural elements
brown.usage: Describes the color of soil or wood

examples: My son is in school - Mwana wami wachalume ali kushikola
He is my son - Ikiye mwana wami wachalume
son.culturalContext: Male children often have specific roles in traditional family

examples: My daughter sings well - Mwana wami wachapwevo emba kanawa
She is my daughter - Ikiye mwana wami wachapwevo
daughter.culturalContext: Female children traditionally learn homemaking skills

examples: My grandfather tells stories - Kaka wami alumwine mishikakimi
I visited my grandfather - Ngwatalilileko kaka wami
grandfather.culturalContext: Respected elder who often passes down cultural knowledge
grandfather.usage: Refers to the father of one's parent

examples: My grandmother makes good food - Nana wami enga kulya chamwaza
I learn from my grandmother - Ngulinangula kuli nana wami
grandmother.culturalContext: Source of wisdom and traditional knowledge
grandmother.usage: Refers to the mother of one's parent

examples: My uncle came to visit - Manjina wami ejile nakutalilikako
I respect my uncle - Ngunenga manjina wami
uncle.culturalContext: May have specific responsibilities to nieces and nephews
uncle.usage: Refers to parent's brother or male relative

examples: My aunt gave me a gift - Tata wami wachapwevo anguhane wana
I am going to my aunt's house - Nguya kuzuvo ya tata wami wachapwevo
aunt.culturalContext: Female relative who may have cultural role in raising children
aunt.usage: Refers to parent's sister or female relative

examples: My cousin lives in the city - Mwanyike wami atwama mumbaka
We grew up with my cousin - Twakula na mwanyike wami
cousin.culturalContext: In extended family structures, cousins may be considered similar to siblings
cousin.usage: Refers to the child of one's aunt or uncle

examples: I want one banana - Ngwatonda likonde chimwe
The banana is ripe - Likonde linakuhya
banana.culturalContext: Common fruit in tropical regions of Zambia
banana.usage: Refers to the yellow curved fruit (singular form)

examples: Monkeys eat bananas - Tuvenga twalya makonde
Ripe bananas are yellow - Makonde akuhya achiyelo
bananas.usage: Refers to the yellow curved fruits (plural form)

examples: Mr. Nkonde is from Northern Zambia - Mwata Nkonde afuma kumushingi wakaseli muchachi chamukawulu
Nkonde.culturalContext: Surname common among people from Northern Zambia, especially among the Bemba and Namwanga peoples
Nkonde.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname, not to be confused with 'likonde' (banana)

examples: Ms. Nalavwe is a teacher - Pwevo Nalavwe muka nangununu
Mr. Nkole is from Muchinga - Mwata Nkole afuma ku Muchinga
Nkole.culturalContext: Surname common among Namwanga and Bemba people in Northern and Muchinga Provinces of Zambia
Nkole.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname meaning 'hill or mountain'

examples: The Silwizya family is respected - Zuvo ya Silwizya yanengisa
Silwizya.culturalContext: Surname found among Tonga and Namwanga communities, associated with warriors and leaders
Silwizya.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname meaning 'one who cannot be defeated in battle'

examples: Mr. Mankungu is a respected elder - Mwata Mankungu ikiye mukulwane wamwaza
Mankungu.culturalContext: Mambwe surname from Northern and Muchinga Provinces of Zambia
Mankungu.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname meaning 'guardian or protector'

examples: Mrs. Mwiiya teaches at the school - Pwevo Mwiiya muka nangununu kushikola
Mwiiya.culturalContext: Lozi surname from Western Province of Zambia
Mwiiya.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname meaning 'educator or teacher'

examples: The Kalombo family lives near the river - Zuvo ya Kalombo yatwama hafwihi nakalwiji
Kalombo.culturalContext: Bemba surname from Northern and Luapula Provinces of Zambia
Kalombo.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname meaning 'small river'

examples: Mr. Sinyangwe is a traditional healer - Mwata Sinyangwe ikiye chimbanda
Sinyangwe.culturalContext: Mambwe and Namwanga surname meaning 'one who cannot be bewitched'
Sinyangwe.usage: Refers to a protective Zambian surname from Northern and Muchinga Provinces

examples: The Chilongo family makes pottery - Zuvo ya Chilongo yapanga jimbisu
Chilongo.culturalContext: Bemba and Lala surname referring to clay pots or vessels
Chilongo.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname associated with pottery-making tradition

examples: Mr. Chilongu is a good speaker - Mwata Chilongu ikiye kahanjiki wamwaza
Chilongu.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname associated with eloquent speaking

examples: Mrs. Kalumba leads the choir - Pwevo Kalumba akutwalajika vakwimba
Kalumba.culturalContext: Bemba and Lunda surname meaning 'one who sings or praises'
Kalumba.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname associated with musical tradition

examples: Mr. Kapolyo is very quick - Mwata Kapolyo ikiye washiwashi chikuma
Kapolyo.usage: Refers to a Zambian surname symbolizing agility and adaptability

examples: Good evening - Chingoloshi mwane
good evening.usage: Used as a greeting in the evening

examples: Good morning - Chimene mwane
good morning.usage: Used as a greeting in the morning

examples: Good afternoon - Musana mwane
good afternoon.usage: Used as a greeting in the afternoon

examples: Good night - Ufuku mwane
good night.usage: Used when parting in the evening or before sleep

examples: How are you? - Munayoyo?
how are you?.usage: Used to inquire about someone's wellbeing

examples: How are you today? - Munayoyo lelo?
how are you today?.usage: Used to inquire about someone's wellbeing on the current day

examples: I am fine - Nguli kanawa
i am fine.usage: Used to respond positively to inquiries about wellbeing

examples: I am fine and you? - Nguli kanawa ngachili yenu?
i am fine and you?.usage: Used to respond to and return an inquiry about wellbeing

examples: Have a good day - Mutome kanawa
have a good day.usage: Used when parting to wish someone a good day

examples: I am doing great - Nguli nakulinga kanawa
i am doing great.usage: Used to respond very positively to inquiries about wellbeing

examples: Hi/Hello - Muli ngachili mwane
Nice to meet you - Chinawahe kulimona ove
nice to meet you.usage: Used when meeting someone for the first time

examples: Goodbye - Salenuho mwane
See you later - Natukalimonenu mwane
see you later.culturalContext: Casual farewell with expectation of meeting again
see you later.usage: Used when parting with the expectation of seeing the person again

examples: I work everyday - Ngwazata hakumbi hakumbi
everyday.usage: Used to indicate something that happens daily

examples: See you tomorrow - Natukalimonenu hamene
tomorrow.usage: Used to refer to the next day

examples: I saw you yesterday - Nakumwene zau
yesterday.usage: Used to refer to the previous day

examples: One month - Kakeji kamwe
Two months - Tukweji tuvali
month/months.usage: Used to refer to a calendar month or months

examples: One day - Likumbi limwe
Many days - Makumbi amavulu
day/days.usage: Used to refer to a day or multiple days

examples: This month is cold - Uno kakweji kuli kututa
this month.usage: Used to refer to the current month

examples: One week - Chalumingo chimwe
Two weeks - Vyalumingo vivali
week/weeks.usage: Used to refer to a week or multiple weeks

examples: I saw you last week - Nakumwene chalumingo chinahichiho
last week.usage: Used to refer to the previous week

examples: One year - Mwaka umwe
Many years - Myaka yayivulu
year/years.usage: Used to refer to a year or multiple years

examples: I will visit next year - Natukayakatala mwaka wauhya
next year.usage: Used to refer to the coming year

examples: How old are you? - Uli namyaka yingahi?
What do you work as? - Wechikuzata milimo muka?
what do you work as?.usage: Used to ask about someone's profession

examples: I am a teacher - Ngumuka mulongeshi
I am a doctor - Ngumuka chimanga
Where do you come from? - Mwafuma kulihi?
where do you come from?.usage: Used to ask about someone's place of origin

examples: I come from Lusaka - Ngwafuma ku Lusaka
i come from.usage: Used to state one's place of origin

examples: I am 25 years old - Nguli namyaka makumi avali nayitanu
What is your name? - Lijina lyenu yenuveya?
My name is John - Lijina lyami yami John
I love you - Ngwakuzanga ove
I miss you - Ngwakuvuluka ove
Love you so much - Ngwakuzanga chikuma ove
love you so much.usage: Used to express intense romantic love

examples: I love you with all my heart - Ngwakuzanga ove na muchima yami
i love you with all my heart.usage: Used to express profound romantic love

examples: I love you too - Ngwakuzanga chikuma ove mwane
i love you too.usage: Used to return an expression of love

examples: I want to see you - Ngwasaka nakumona ove
i want to see you.usage: Used to express desire to meet

examples: I like you - Ngwasaka ove
i like you.usage: Used to express fondness or attraction

examples: You are beautiful - Uli na litanana
My love - Zangi yami
my love.usage: Used as an affectionate address to a romantic partner

examples: You look beautiful - Uli nakumona litanana
My beautiful wife - Lisano lyami na litanana
my beautiful wife.usage: Used as an affectionate address to one's wife

examples: I miss you so much, darling - Ngwakuvuluka chikuma wakuzanga
i miss you so much, darling.usage: Used to express intense missing for a loved one

examples: I need you - Ngwakutonda ove
i need you.usage: Used to express emotional need for someone

examples: You will miss me - Uli nakuya kukushinganyeka chikuma ami
you will miss me.usage: Used to suggest someone will miss you

examples: Goodbye, my love - Salenuho mwane, zangi yami
goodbye, my love.usage: Used to say goodbye to a romantic partner

examples: See you tomorrow - Natukalimonenu hamene mwane
see you tomorrow.usage: Used when parting with plans to meet the next day

examples: I will marry you - Nangumumbate ove
i will marry you.usage: Used to propose or promise marriage

examples: Stay well - Mulanjise kanawa
stay well.usage: Used when parting to wish someone good health

examples: I want some space - Ngwasaka space
i want some space.usage: Used to express desire for emotional or physical distance

examples: I need your love - Ngwasaka zangi yove
i need your love.usage: Used to express desire for someone's affection

examples: You are mine - Uli wami
